sen.j: 彦坐王（ひこいますのみこ、生没年不詳）は、記紀に伝えられる古墳時代の皇族（王族）。
sen.e: Prince Hikoimasu [Hikoimasu no Miko (彦坐王); His date of birth and death are unknown.] first appeared in the "Record of Ancient Matters" and "Chronicles of Japan," as he was an Imperial family (Royal family) during the Kofun period (tumulus period) in Japan.

Prince Hikoimasu (Hikoimasu no Miko [彦坐王]; His date of birth and death are unknown.) first appeared in the "Record of Ancient Matters" and "Chronicles of Japan," as he was a member of an Imperial family (Royal family) during the Kofun period (tumulus period) in Japan.
sen.cmt: () [ ]の修正を行いました。（原文は使用する括弧の種類が逆転していました。）As he以下の文にa member ofを追記しました。
sen.e: Prince Hikoimasu (Hikoimasu no Miko [彦坐王]; His date of birth and death are unknown.) first appeared in the "Record of Ancient Matters" and "Chronicles of Japan," as he was a member of an Imperial family (Royal family) during the Kofun period (tumulus period) in Japan.

sen.j: 彦坐命、日子坐王、彦今簀命とも。
sen.e: Prince Hikoimasu (彦坐王) was also know as "(彦坐命) Hikoimasu no Mikoto," "(日子坐王) Hikoimasu no Miko," and "(彦今簀命) Hikoimasu no Mikoto."
Prince Hikoimasu (彦坐王) was also known as "(彦坐命) Hikoimasu no Mikoto," "(日子坐王) Hikoimasu no Miko," and "(彦今簀命) Hikoimasu no Mikoto."
Prince Hikoimasu (彦坐王) was also known as "(彦坐命) Hikoimasu no Mikoto," "(日子坐王) Hikoimasu no Miko," and "(彦今簀命) Hikoimasu no Mikoto."

sen.j: 開化天皇の第3皇子。
sen.e: Prince Hikoimasu was the third Prince of the Emperor Kaika.
Prince Hikoimasu was the third Prince of the Emperor Kaika.
Prince Hikoimasu was the third Prince of the Emperor Kaika.

sen.j: 母は姥津命の妹・姥津媛命（ははつひめのみこと）。
sen.e: The mother of Prince Hikoimasu was, a younger sister of 'Hahatsu Mikoto,' 'Hahatsuhime no Mikoto.'
The mother of Prince Hikoimasu was a younger sister of 'Hahatsu Mikoto,' 'Hahatsuhime no Mikoto.'
sen.cmt: wasのあとのカンマを削除しました。
sen.e: The mother of Prince Hikoimasu was a younger sister of 'Hahatsu Mikoto,' 'Hahatsuhime no Mikoto.'

sen.j: 崇神天皇の異母弟、景行天皇の曾祖父、神功皇后の高祖父にあたる。
sen.e: Prince Hikoimasu was the younger paternal brother of the Emperor Sujin, was a great-grandfather of the Emperor Keiko, and a great-great-grandfather of the Empress Jingu.
Prince Hikoimasu was the younger paternal brother of the Emperor Sujin, a great-grandfather of the Emperor Keiko, and a great-great-grandfather of the Empress Jingu.
Prince Hikoimasu was the younger paternal brother of the Emperor Sujin, a great-grandfather of the Emperor Keiko, and a great-great-grandfather of the Empress Jingu.

sen.j: 『古事記』によると、王は崇神天皇の命を受け、玖賀耳之御笠（くがみみのみかさ）退治。
sen.e: According to "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), Prince Hikoimasu received an order from the Emperor Sujin to destroy 'Kugamimi no Mikasa.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: According to "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), Prince Hikoimasu received an order from the Emperor Sujin to destroy 'Kugamimi no Mikasa.'
According to "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), Prince Hikoimasu received an order from the Emperor Sujin to destroy 'Kugamimi no Mikasa.'

sen.j: そのために、丹波に派遣されたとある。
sen.e: Thus, Prince Hikoimasu was sent to Tamba.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Thus, Prince Hikoimasu was sent to Tamba.
Thus, Prince Hikoimasu was sent to Tamba.

sen.j: 稗史によれば、彦坐王は美濃国を領地として、子の八瓜入日子とともに治山治水開発に努めたとも伝えられる。
sen.e: According to the Haishi (Old Chinese story driven History book), Prince Hikoimasu ruled his territory, Mino Province; and the Haisi told the story of how Prince Hikoimasu and his child, 'Yatsuriirihiko-no-O,' endeavored to develop forest conservation and flood control.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: According to the Haishi (Old Chinese story driven History book), Prince Hikoimasu ruled his territory, Mino Province; and the Haisi told the story of how Prince Hikoimasu and his child, 'Yatsuriirihiko-no-O,' endeavored to develop forest conservation and flood control.

According to the Haishi (Old Chinese story driven History book), Prince Hikoimasu ruled his territory, Mino Province where he endeavored to develop forest conservation and flood control together with his child, 'Yatsuriirihiko-no-O,'
sen.cmt: ; and the Haisi told the story of how Prince Hikoimasu and his child, ‘Yatsuriirihiko-no-O,’ endeavored to develop forest conservation and flood control.→where he endeavored to develop forest conservation and flood control together with his child, ‘Yatsuriirihiko-no-O,’としました。

sen.j: しかし、その後裔氏族は美濃のみならず、常陸国・甲斐国・三河国・伊勢国・近江国・山城国・河内国・大和国・但馬国・播磨国・丹波国・吉備国・若狭国・因幡国など広汎に分布している。
sen.e: Later, the clan descendants were not exclusively limited to the Mino province, but were able to expand upon their territories into many different places; such as: Hitachi Province, Kai Province, Mikawa Province, Ise Province, Omi Province, Yamashiro Province, Kawachi Province, Yamato Province, Tajima Province, Harima Province, Tanba Province, Kibi Province, Wakasa Province, and Inaba Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Later, the clan descendants were not exclusively limited to the Mino province, but were able to expand upon their territories into many different places; such as: Hitachi Province, Kai Province, Mikawa Province, Ise Province, Omi Province, Yamashiro Province, Kawachi Province, Yamato Province, Tajima Province, Harima Province, Tanba Province, Kibi Province, Wakasa Province, and Inaba Province.

Besides the Mino province, his descendants expanded upon their territories into many different places such as Hitachi Province, Kai Province, Mikawa Province, Ise Province, Omi Province, Yamashiro Province, Kawachi Province, Yamato Province, Tajima Province, Harima Province, Tanba Province, Kibi Province, Wakasa Province and Inaba Province.

sen.j: 時代は下るが、戦国時代 (日本)に大名となった越前朝倉氏は本姓日下部氏である。
sen.e: At a much later time period in this history, the Echizen-Asakura clan became a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) during the Sengoku period (period of warring states) in Japan, having had the original name of the Kusakabe clan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: At a much later time period in this history, the Echizen-Asakura clan became a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) during the Sengoku period (period of warring states) in Japan, having had the original name of the Kusakabe clan.

At a much later time period in this history, the Echizen-Asakura clan became a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) during the Sengoku period (period of warring states) in Japan, having had the original name of the Kusakabe clan.

sen.j: 日下部氏は、彦坐王の子孫と称する但馬国造家の流れを汲んでいる。
sen.e: Then, the Kusakabe clan was lineage to the 'Tanba Kuni no miyatsuko (regional administrator)'family, which claimed to be descended from Prince Hikoimasu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Then, the Kusakabe clan was lineage to the 'Tanba Kuni no miyatsuko (regional administrator)' family, which claimed to be descended from Prince Hikoimasu.
sen.cmt: ’を半角表記に修正しました。
sen.e: Then, the Kusakabe clan was lineage to the 'Tanba Kuni no miyatsuko (regional administrator)' family, which claimed to be descended from Prince Hikoimasu.

sen.j: 大阪府堺市・日部神社の祭神の他、岐阜市岩田の伊波乃西神社でも祀られてある。
sen.e: Kusakabe Shrine is located in Sakai City, Osaka Prefecture, and Iwanonishi Shrine is located in Iwata, Gifu City, each worship Prince Hikoimasu [Hikoimasu no Mikoto (日子坐命)].
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Prince Hikoimasu (Hikoimasu no Mikoto [日子坐命]) has been enshrined in both Kusakabe-jinja Shrine located in Sakai City, Osaka Prefecture, and Iwanonishi-jinja Shrine located in Iwata, Gifu City.
sen.cmt: 神社名の表記を仕様書に従い統一しました。() [ ]の位置が逆のため修正しました。そのうえで、文構造が誤っているため原文にあわせて修正しました。
sen.e: Prince Hikoimasu (Hikoimasu no Mikoto [日子坐命]) has been enshrined in both Kusakabe-jinja Shrine located in Sakai City, Osaka Prefecture, and Iwanonishi-jinja Shrine located in Iwata, Gifu City.

sen.j: 同社の近くには日子坐命の墓（宮内庁が管理）とされる巨岩がある。
sen.e: Also, there is the megalith which is said to be the grave of Prince Hikoimasu (The Imperial Household Agency manages this place.), nearby to the Iwanonishi Shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Also, there is the megalith which is said to be the grave of Prince Hikoimasu (The Imperial Household Agency manages this place.), near the Iwanonishi-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: nearby to=>nearに修正しました。神社名表記を統一しました。
sen.e: Also, there is the megalith which is said to be the grave of Prince Hikoimasu (The Imperial Household Agency manages this place.), near the Iwanonishi-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 彦坐王（日子坐命）の王子女は『古事記』に詳しいが、『日本書紀』ではほとんど触れられていない。
sen.e: Inside "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), Princes and Princesses of Prince Hikoimasu [(Hikoimasu no Mikoto (日子坐命)] were written in detail, but there were rare written articles about the Princes and Princesses inside the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), Princes and Princesses of Prince Hikoimasu (Hikoimasu no Mikoto [日子坐命]) were written in detail, but there were rare written articles about the Princes and Princesses in "the Nihonshoki" (the Chronicles of Japan).
sen.cmt: Inside => Inに修正しました。() [ ]の位置が逆のため修正しました。日本書紀の前のtheを" "内にいれ、Chroniclesの前にもtheを追記しました。
sen.e: In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), Princes and Princesses of Prince Hikoimasu (Hikoimasu no Mikoto [日子坐命]) were written in detail, but there were rare written articles about the Princes and Princesses in "the Nihonshoki" (the Chronicles of Japan).

sen.j: 妃：袁祁都比売命（おけつひめのみこと、彦姥津命の妹）
sen.e: Prince: 'Oketsuhime no Mikoto' (a younger sister of 'Hikooketsu no Mikoto')
Princess: 'Oketsuhime no Mikoto' (a younger sister of 'Hikooketsu no Mikoto')

sen.e: He was a great-grandfather of the Empress Jingu and the ancestor of 'Tanba Kuni no miyatsuko (regional administrator).'

sen.j: 日葉酢媛命（垂仁天皇の皇后（後）・景行天皇の母）の父・三河宝飯郡別の祖。
sen.e: He was the father of 'Hibasuhime no Mikoto' (the Empress of the Emperor Suinin (later) and the mother of the Emperor Keiko) and the ancestor of the 'Lord of the Hoi County in Mikawa Province.'

sen.j: なお、『先代旧事本紀』国造本紀因幡国造条に「彦坐王児彦多都彦命」と見える。
sen.e: Additionally, there was a written article on "A child of Prince Hikoimasu (Hikoimasu no Miko), Hikotatsuhiko (彦多都彦命)" in the articles of 'Inaba no kunimiyatsuko,' which were written inside the document: Sendai Kujihongi (Ancient Japanese History), and in a section of the Kokuzo hongi (the original record of provincial governors).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Additionally, there was a written article on "A child of Prince Hikoimasu (Hikoimasu no Miko), Hikotatsuhiko (彦多都彦命)" in the articles of 'Inaba no kunimiyatsuko,' which were written in the document: Sendai Kujihongi (Ancient Japanese History), and in a section of the Kokuzo hongi (the original record of provincial governors).

Additionally, there was a written article on "A child of Prince Hikoimasu (Hikoimasu no Miko), Hikotatsuhiko (彦多都彦命)" in the articles of 'Inaba no kunimiyatsuko,' which were written in the document: Sendai Kujihongi (Ancient Japanese History), and in a section of the Kokuzo hongi (the original record of provincial governors).

sen.j: しかし、不詳である。
sen.e: But, this child went unidentified.
